channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Republican Says Iran Deal Should Halt Uranium Enrichment
item.description: Ed Royce, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, laid down a marker on a comprehensive Iran accord during a hearing that included testimony by Secretary of State John Kerry.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Prominent Rights Lawyer Among 4 Abducted in Syria
item.description: The abduction of the lawyer, Razan Zeitouneh, came hours after relatives and colleagues of two Spanish journalists kidnapped by Islamists in September in northern Syria made their plight public.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: The Lede: Show Us Your Scenes From Mandela’s Farewell
item.description: If you are in South Africa to pay tribute to Nelson Mandela, we invite you to share a photograph with us of the scenes and details you are witnessing at memorials and in the streets.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Prayers for Nelson Mandela at Heavenly Gate, a small church in Diepsloot, outside Johannesburg on Sunday.

item.title: After Mandela, a Test at the Polls for His Party
item.description: After the death of its most beloved leader, the African National Congress could face its most competitive elections since it came to power in 1994.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: Diepsloot, a settlement north of Johannesburg, where other parties have made inroads on the African National Congress.

item.title: Chinese Professor Who Advocated Free Speech Is Fired
item.description: Zhang Xuezhong, who teaches at the East China University of Political Science and Law in Shanghai, has repeatedly called on the Chinese government to abide by its own Constitution.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Will Handshake With Castro Lead to Headache for Obama?
item.description: President Obama’s gesture to Raúl Castro of Cuba at the memorial for Nelson Mandela instantly raised questions about its deeper meaning.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama shook hands with President Raúl Castro of Cuba on Tuesday during the memorial service for Nelson Mandela.

item.title: Defective Breast Implant Sales Draw Prison Term for French Executive
item.description: The founder of Poly Implant Prothèse got four years in prison for selling hundreds of thousands of defective implants in more than 65 countries.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: The Great and the Humble Pay Tribute to Mandela
item.description: Nelson Mandela’s rain-swept memorial service drew tens of thousands of South Africans and a large crowd of global V.I.P.’s, including President Obama and more than 90 other heads of state and government.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN, NICHOLAS KULISH and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A crush of people sang songs, stomped their feet and shouted the name of the man whose life they had come to celebrate.

item.title: Letter from Europe: Vindication, of Sorts, for Austerity in Britain
item.description: Britain’s recent burst of economic growth calls for a re-examination of its unpopular austerity measures, which critics contend have hurt the country’s recovery.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: South Africa Faces Its Future
item.description: In the shadow of Nelson Mandela’s death, four South Africans ponder a future without the man who inspired and set so many free.

item.title: Obama, George W. Bush and Hillary Clinton Share Flight to South Africa
item.description: A former president, a current president and a potential candidate for president shared Air Force One for the flight to South Africa.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama, Michelle Obama, former President George W. Bush and Laura Bush arrived in Johannesburg.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 10
item.description: A demonstration on Human Rights Day in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: An activist during a demonstration on Human Rights Day in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir. The day marks the adoption of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights by the United Nations General Assembly.

item.title: Ukraine’s President Convenes ‘Round Table’
item.description: Using a term borrowed from the Orange Revolution, President Viktor F. Yanukovich made plans to meet with former politicians to discuss solutions to the country’s problems.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Thai Leader Rejects Demands That She Quit
item.description: Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra on refused to step aside before the country’s February elections.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: India Ink: Delhi’s Popular Chief Minister Couldn’t Escape Anti-Congress Wave
item.description: Though Sheila Dikshit could boast of substantial achievements during her 15-year reign, she had no answer for the voters who soured on her Congress Party.
item.dc:creator: By VAIBHAV VATS
item.media:description: Sheila Dikshit, center, chief minister of Delhi, during a press conference in New Delhi on Sunday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Activist’s Computer Did Not Have Spyware, N.Y.U. Says
item.description: Chen Guangcheng, a human rights advocate from China who fled to the United States, did not have his smartphone and tablet compromised by spyware, New York University said more than a year after making the assertion.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Video of Violent Hazing in Paramilitary Unit Stirs Dismay in China
item.description: A leaked video shows members of the country’s People’s Armed Police beating new recruits, a glimpse of hazing rarely seen in China. The authorities apologized and promised an investigation.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A video showing firefighters undergoing violent hazing has circulated widely online.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Stumbling Block for Turkey’s Missile Deal With China
item.description: A defense bill before the United States Congress may undercut Turkey’s agreement to buy air-defense missile systems from China.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY DOYLE
item.media:description: A Dutch Army Patriot defense missile system was set up at an air base in Turkey in January.

item.title: India Ink: Women’s Voices Go Unheard Within Walls of Ahmedabad Ghetto
item.description: In Juhapura, female participation in the political process is limited by cultural pressure to avoid political topics and by the lack of spaces where women can freely express themselves.
item.dc:creator: By RAKSHA KUMAR
item.media:description: A makeshift market in Juhapura in Ahmedabad, Gujarat.

item.title: China Is Tied to Spying on European Diplomats
item.description: The foreign ministries of five countries were reportedly breached by Chinese hackers using emails as bait.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Delay Foreseen in Removing Syrian Chemicals
item.description: The leader of the group helping oversee the destruction of Syria’s chemical arms said that meeting a Dec. 31 export deadline would be difficult.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Mayor Ousted in Colombia After Claims of Bungling
item.description: The Bogotá mayor, Gustavo Petro, was said to have made serious mistakes in his handling of the botched transfer of garbage collection from private contractors to a government-run service.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Mayor Gustavo Petro of Bogotá in 2012. He can appeal his dismissal.

item.title: Ukrainian Protesters Struggle to Keep Police and Cold at Bay
item.description: A confrontation at a tiny camp of Ukrainian protesters was an example of the seesaw struggle with the police for control of strategic areas in Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cooks prepared food at the camp in Independence Square in Kiev on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Looking on the Bright Side of Bad Air
item.description: The heavy air pollution covering much of eastern China recently has prompted intense coverage in the Chinese media, some of it humorous, showing that Chinese residents have a far better idea now of what they are breathing than they did just a few years ago, when such information was considered sensitive.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Searches for "air pollution" in China in recent years, according to Google.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China to End Loophole in Child Rape Law, Experts Say
item.description: A deeply unpopular law in China that effectively gave men having sex with under-14s lighter criminal punishments than those who committed rape will be abolished, according to lawyers.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
